‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: pretty straight forward but not easy

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I think it is a good contribution.

I'm instantly thinking about scenarios when a student mistakes the punctuation in the end, instead of forgetting.

How should the solution handle the following cases:
How did I get there ;
Who wrote this ?.?
Did I forget to put a question mark

Do we expect "How did I get there ?", "Who wrote this ?" and "Did I forget to put a question mark ?" as results ?

I would suggest to add them as tests and validators.
Also add Does, Did, Do, Is, Was, Will question words along the other key words described in rule 1.

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Fun clash that tests string handling, suitable for all players
To be honest, you‚Äôre right! I really found it enjoyable and challenging at the same time. Excellent work!

Just tested your clash, and I think it's quite interesting! Here are some comments I have:

- For absolute clarity, please define a word as a consecutive sequence of letters, and a sentence as a sequence of words separated by spaces.

- I think it is safe to remove rule 2, since you make no reference to "marks" anywhere else in the problem statement. Your phrase "X is the number of correct sentences" seems to convey your intention well enough.
Either that, or rephrase rule 2 as "Each sentence that follows the rule is deemed correct."

- Please specify the output of corrected sentences to appear in the order given in the input; e.g., "<<Next lines>>: The corrected version of all wrong sentences (if any), each on its own line, in the order given in the input."

- Please rephrase the second constraint to: "Each sentence contains only letters and spaces, except for the last character, which will either be {{.}} or {{?}}.

- Please include at least one test case where N > 1 (ideally for a larger N) and all sentences are correct. Similarly, include another test case where N > 1 and all sentences are wrong. Mix the statements and questions for each case.

- Consider randomising the casing of the first word of each sentence (or for all words if you choose). You currently utilise both lowercase and sentence case; I would think that uppercase refers to sentences such as "WHAT ARE YOU DOING?".
You can also play around with other cases such as camelCase, PascalCase, tOGGLE cASE, sPoNgEcAsE, etc.
Enjoyed playing it!

General
* All sections should use the following formatting where appropriate:
‚Ä¢ Variables: [[variable]]
‚Ä¢ Constants: {{constant}}
‚Ä¢ Bold text: <<bold>>

More details are provided below.

Goal
* Please format the question words "how", "where", "when", "why", "who", "what" as {{constants}} (remember to exclude the commas between them when formatting).

* Please format "?" and "." as {{constants}}.

* Please format "X/N" as "[[X]]{{/}}[[N]]".

* Please format "X" and "N" as [[variables]].

* Please remove the quotation marks around "?", ".", "X" and "N".

* Please add the following after "what),":

regardless of whether it is written in uppercase or lowercase,

Input
* Both lines: Please format "N" as a [[variable]] and remove the quotation marks around "N".

* Please format "Line 1" and "Next N lines" in <<bold>>.

Output
* Please format "X/N" as "[[X]]{{/}}[[N]]".

* Please format "Line 1" and "Next lines" in <<bold>>.

* Please change "were" to "are".

Constraints
* Please format "N" as a [[variable]].

* Please change 100 to 10.

* Please change "letters, spaces" to "letters and spaces".

* Please format "." and "?" as {{constants}}.

* Please delete the last two constraints, since they're NOT constraints, and they're already covered in the Goal section.

Game modes
* Reverse mode may be too difficult, since it requires gathering all question words. Consider disabling Reverse mode.

Cases
* Multiple Statements (Validator 4): Please remove the trailing newline from the output.

* Each test and its corresponding validator must be similar. Please split all cases into separate test/validator pairs. For example,

Test 1: Simple Correct Statement (test)
Validator 1: Simple Correct Statement (validator)
Test 2: Simple Wrong Statement (test)
Validator 2: Simple Wrong Statement (validator)

* Case Insensitive Check (test 4):
  ‚Ä¢ All sentences should start with a lowercase letter.
  ‚Ä¢ Statements should be covered in addition to questions.

* Please ensure all question words appear in BOTH tests AND validators.

Thanks.
i have made the changes , please check it
thankyou

Thankyou for playing .
I made the changes in the problem 
For some of your suggestions -

"Please include at least one test case where N > 1 (ideally for a larger N) and all sentences are correct. Similarly, include another test case where N > 1 and all sentences are wrong. Mix the statements and questions for each case" - 
for that i don't think it would make any difference from any approach , and i think same for this - 
Consider randomising the casing of the first word of each sentence (or for all words if you choose). You currently utilise both lowercase and sentence case; I would think that uppercase refers to sentences such as "WHAT ARE YOU DOING?".
You can also play around with other cases such as camelCase, PascalCase, tOGGLE cASE, sPoNgEcAsE, etc.

but if you find a loophole in the given cases let me know that would be awesome .
Thankyou!
Thankyou for the approval

Man this question could be made tougher by adding different scenarios, i kept it simple and easy to match clash of code and be solvable under 2-3 minutes , ain't no one is going to be able to solve the problem which in initially intended it to be to correct the whole grammar of the sentence under 5 minutes
thankyou
That's why the second constraint is there: it clarifies that the scenarios mentioned by @DinoFromChrome and other possible more complex scenarios won't be tested.

I proposed having a mix of wrong statements and questions to "stress test" having to output every sentence from the input to the output in its corrected form. It doesn't change the approach of the question. Similarly for having a test case where all statements/questions are correct; it is merely another edge case. The reasoning is similar for the mixed casing. Thank you.

I agree with @User123's suggestions:

- Please rephrase the second constraint to: "Each sentence contains only letters and spaces, except for the last character, which will either be {{.}} or {{?}}.

- Consider randomising the casing of the first word of each sentence (or for all words if you choose). You currently utilise both lowercase and sentence case; I would think that uppercase refers to sentences such as "WHAT ARE YOU DOING?".
You can also play around with other cases such as camelCase, PascalCase, tOGGLE cASE, sPoNgEcAsE, etc.

For the second point, it's always better to include additional scenarios, since we can't assume how a player's code is implemented. For example, their code might correctly handle a word in proper case or all lowercase, but fail in other cases.

@nikhilhuh, could you please follow up?

Also, I noticed you approved this contribution ( https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/1343580db502e42c8a478fdd9c14700f30349a ) before the author addressed the issues I mentioned in my comment. In this case, the author later fixed them, so it's fine. But in the future, could you please check others' comments first and make sure that all noted issues are resolved before approving?

Thank you.

i have changes the second constraint and add a test where different cases of sentences are there , and a validator where all sentences are correct , by this all the various aspects the problem are covered

Test 6
* Please add:
  ‚Ä¢ one sentence which begins with a question word of mixed casing and ends with "."
  ‚Ä¢ one sentence which begins with a question word of mixed casing and ends with "?"
  ‚Ä¢ one sentence which begins with a word (not a question word) of mixed casing but ends with "?"

Validator 6
* Same point as Test 6 above.

Thanks.
done
OK, thank you.

Thank you. The following is the updated list of adjustments to make.

Goal
* Please change "{{what}} ," to "{{what}}, " (the space should be after the comma, not before it).

* Please add "or" before "{{what}}".

Constraints
* Please change 100 to 10.

* Please delete the last two constraints, since they're NOT constraints, and they're already covered in the Goal section.

Cases
* Test 3 and Validator 3: Please change the names to "Multiple Sentences".
  
* Test 3
  ‚Ä¢ Please increase N to 7 and add:
    - A statement which ends with "?"
    - A question which starts with "How" and ends with "."
    - A question which starts with "Where" and ends with "."
    - A question which starts with "What" and ends with "."

* Validator 3
  ‚Ä¢¬†Please increase N to 6 and add:
    - A question which starts with "How" and ends with "?"
    - A question which starts with "Where" and ends with "?"
    - A question which starts with "When" and ends with "?"

* Case Insensitive (Test 4)
  ‚Ä¢ Please change "Where" to "where".
  ‚Ä¢ Please increase N to 8 and add (all lowercase):
    - A statement which starts with a lowercase letter and ends with "?"
    - A statement which starts with a lowercase letter and ends with "."
    - A question which starts with "how" and ends with "?"
    - A question which starts with "what" and ends with "?"
    - A question which starts with "why" and ends with "?"
    - A question which starts with "when" and ends with "."

* Case Insensitive (Test 4)
  ‚Ä¢ Please change "Who" to "who".
  ‚Ä¢ Please increase N to 8 and add (all question words in lowercase):
    - A statement which starts with a lowercase letter and ends with "?"
    - A statement which starts with a lowercase letter and ends with "."
    - A question which starts with "how" and ends with "."
    - A question which starts with "where" and ends with "."
    - A question which starts with "when" and ends with "."
    - A question which starts with "why" and ends with "?"

Thanks again.
done

We're almost there!

Goal
* Please add "or" before "{{what}}".

Cases
* Case Insensitive (test): Please change "don't" to "do not" to comply with the second constraint.

* Case Insensitive (validator): Please change "don't" to "do not" to comply with the second constraint.

Thanks.

Please also add Test 5 and Validator 5, which feature one of the question words appearing in the *middle* of a sentence. In each case, there should be two sentences: one sentence should end with "." and the other with "?". For example:

You know how to get there.
This is where I live?

Thanks.

actually the test 5 is not what the question intends to do , this question was made to be done under 2-3 minutes and for that the constraints are that if the sentence is a question it will begin with a question word otherwise not.
i have done those changes

But it's a perfectly valid sentence that can be in the scope of the task. The player should check whether a question word is at the beginning of a sentence to determine whether it's a question, not merely checking whether the question word is present or not.
Also, adding such cases doesn't increase the complexity of the task.

Please add Test 6 and Validator 6 where the first word of a sentence *contains* a question word but isn't the question word itself, e.g.

Whoever knows the answer is a genius?
Wherever you go I will go with you.

Thanks.

if i add test cases where these are the sentences- 
You know how to get there.
This is where I live?
then output will become 
1/2
This is where I live.

Because the first rule of the statement says that the question will begin with the words (written in the rule 1), but as you can clearly see grammatically correct output should be 
0/2
You know how to get there?
This is where I live.

I hope you understand the difference , but what you are saying is right and i first intended the question to be that only but while solving it took me close to 5 minutes which clearly does not fulfill the criteria for Clash of code.

The task is to check whether the punctuation is correct based on whether the first word of the sentence is a question word.

There's nothing in the statement which suggests that a question word appearing in the middle of a sentence would make that sentence grammatically incorrect, if that sentence ends with a full-stop.

Also, the complexity won't increase if you use a very simple approach to solve it:
1. Split the sentence with the space character as the delimiter.
2. Change the first word to lowercase and check whether it is one of the question words.
3. If correct, increase the score.
4. If not correct, correct the punctuation.

If you don't want to split the sentence into words, and you just want to check the first few number of characters to see if any question word is the first word, it's slightly more cumbersome, but such an approach still works with the new cases suggested.

Even if the new cases (Test/Validator 5/6) are added, the above approach won't change. I don't see how the complexity increases or the time required to solve the problem will increase significantly.

Hope this clarifies.

i thought you were asking me to add test cases where the question word is in between for eg- 
Can you tell me why he left?

Like these
